speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to lead off the debate on the government's budget for the
1992-93 fiscal year.
I would like to start by congratulating my colleague, the Minister of Finance, on a budget that reflects the concerns of Canadians. He not only heard what they had to say. He listened. This is truly a budget for all Canadians, not just for the government.
During pre-budget consultations, there was a clear consensus on the need for adopting a well balanced approach that would help strengthen our economy today and in the years to come.
The Budget
Mr. Speaker, I think it is clear, and you and I heard the minister say, that Canadians want to cut the deficit. They know that higher debt means higher taxes, and they want an end to rising taxes. They want the burden of government reduced. They want less government and better service.
Canadians want to ensure better development of Canada's most valuable resource-our people. They want better opportunities for people to improve their skills, and they want steps taken to ensure that our social programs meet the basic needs of Canadians.
Most of all, Canadians want a renewed basis for confidence in their economy-confidence that jobs will be created and jobs maintained.
The budget is a response to these demands. The equation is quite simple: The budget will cut public spending and use the savings to provide tax reductions that will help Canadian citizens and support economic growth.

This budget will not please anyone who thinks we can spend our way to instant prosperity. My colleague, the Minister of Finance, said yesterday that you don't get out of a hole by digging it deeper. The budget of course makes tough decisions to reduce government spending. These cuts make it possible for us not only to reduce the deficit but also to cut taxes and deliver a social dividend to Canadians and their families.

The personal income surtax will drop from 5 per cent of basic tax to 4 per cent on July 1,1992, and to 3 per cent on January 1, 1993. This will increase Canadians' aftertax income by $500 million in 1992-93, and by more than $1.2 billion in 1993-94. Every one of the nearly 15 million taxpayers will benefit from it.
The new home buyers' plan will allow Canadians to draw on their registered retirement savings plans to buy a house. Individuals will be able to withdraw up to $20,000 tax-free and repay it over 15 years.
Interest rates have declined considerably, about seven points since the spring of 1990, and Canadians are very pleased with that. Similarly one-year mortgage rates have fallen sue percentage points. Thus a family that takes out a $75,000 mortgage loan amortized over 25 years saves over $300 a month. Lower inflation is the key to lower interest rates. Inflation has dropped spectacu-

February 26, 1992
The Budget
larly, from a 6.8 per cent annual rate in January 1991 to barely 1.6 per cent today.

The manufacturing and processing sector exports some 40 per cent of its production and is highly exposed to international competition. To help it meet the challenges of globalization, the manufacturing and processing tax will be reduced from 23 per cent to 22 per cent by January 1, 1994.
Furthermore the capital cost allowance rate will be increased for manufacturing and processing machinery from 25 per cent to 30 per cent.

The budget also recognizes the crucial role that research and development play in today's global economy. We are streamlining the administration of the scientific research tax credit. This should enable businesses to make greater use of the credit and stimulate about $230 million of research and development in the next few years.
The government is setting up the Small Businesses Financing Program to help small businesses, which are so important to the Canadian economy, obtain loans at lower interest rates. Furthermore the ceiling for loans to small businesses under the Small Businesses Loans Act will double to $200,000.

As one can see this budget makes a concrete investment in overcoming our current economic weakness, in reducing the burden of deficits and taxes, and in building a more competitive future. But it also invests new resources in assisting Canada's children, the disabled and students. The government has proposed major reform of the child benefit system. The new system will increase child benefits by $400 million per year and target them to low and middle income families. I will come back to this proposal in a moment.
The budget also includes measures to help disabled persons play a fuller role in Canadian life. For example, the range of tax deductible expenses for medical treatments Mil be broadened.
The budget will also provide additional tax relief to students. The maximum amount of income on which the education credit is calculated will increase by one-third. The limit of the total amount of tuition fees and education credits which may be transferred to another taxpayer will rise to $680.
Even as the government is being streamlined, measures will be taken to improve service to the public. For example, departments and agencies will work to provide more convenient one-step access to the services they offer. Standards of service will be developed for such matters as longer hours of opening and faster responses. Procedures and forms will be simplified and existing regulations will be reviewed to ensure they serve valid public purposes.
Yesterday in the budget we saw a major $2 billion step toward improving federal support for children and families.
The new child benefit will consolidate the existing family allowances, child tax credits and dependent child credit into a single monthly benefit beginning January 1993. The child benefit will also include an additional amount for low income working families.
It is the largest and most important social initiative since the child tax credit was introduced in 1978. The proposed child benefits built on existing federal programs for children and families total $15 billion annually.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to tell you today why we are taking this action. To begin, I would like to quote something that I read recently: "Children are an asset to the state, human resources are of much more importance than material resources". Those words were spoken by then Prime Minister Mackenzie King in the House of Commons in July 1944, nearly half a century ago, when the family allowances bill was presented. He also said: "There is an obligation upon the state to assist in the upbringing of children" and "the family and the home are the foundation of national life". To be sure, politicians are rarely unanimous. However, when the importance of children and families is concerned, I am sure that we can agree.
February 26, 1992



We plan to discuss this proposal with the provinces however. We plan to discuss implementation and not introduction. In fact we will be introducing legislation before the summer and I hope we will receive support from all members of the House.
We want the kind of support that Mackenzie King received in 1944. Adjusting the way we support children and families is a hallmark of Canada's social policy tradition.
Since 1945 successive federal governments have made additions and adjustments to our child benefit programs. These programs have been modified on more than 20 separate occasions. Each of these changes were made with good reason. Each was appropriate to its time, but the result of all these additions and adjustments is a patchwork of benefits.
It is complicated. It makes little sense. It tries to be fair, but it falls short in that regard, too.

The new child benefit follows up the recommendations of two parliamentary reports, one from a Senate committee entitled Child Poverty: Towards a Better Future, and another from a House subcommittee entitled Canada's Children: Our Future. The recommendations were very good. We have accepted and implemented them.

The new child benefit has three characteristics. First, it is simpler. There is no additional paperwork to fill out. It is tax free for parents to keep and benefit their children. An all in one payment is made every month. It is fairer.
The new child benefit will be based on the over-all income of the family and not on individual incomes. It will go to families who need it. To help working families better provide for their children, there is an earned income supplement of $500 per family.
Finally it is more generous. Virtually all single parents and one earner families will receive more. Annual benefits for low to moderate income families with
The Budget
incomes below $50,000 will increase by an average of almost $250 a year.
I believe it is a fiscally responsive decision and that fiscal responsibility is itself a social benefit. Our children must not inherit a Canada that is crippled by debt.
Of course some will say this is the end of universal social programs. I believe it is a reaffirmation of Canadians' belief in fairness. I cannot justify sending a family allowance cheque or giving a child tax credit to families that earn hundreds of thousands of dollars. It is just not fair.

On the contrary, I think that as a society, whether we are politicians or ordinary citizens, we cannot remain indifferent when children go to school hungry or do not have boots to wear in winter.
If we want to help children, we must help families. Of course the government does not have unlimited resources so it must make the best use of them.

Every generation leaves the next a legacy. We all struggle to do our best for our children. As we make these efforts, we also recognize that our children will one day have to make their own way in the world. We must give them every opportunity.
Prosperity is not a commodity that can be bought or sold. It is not something that can be handed down from one generation to the next. Prosperity is the result of a healthy, happy, educated and motivated collection of people. Certainly prosperity has something to do with money, but it has a lot more to do with people. Tomorrow's prosperity is in the hands of today's children. The legacy we must leave them is one of unrestricted opportunity. They must inherit from us a future that is wide open, free for them to make the paths they will.

All the measures described, together with the initiatives that the government has taken in the past, strengthen the foundation for growth and job creation. As the Minister of Finance reminded us yesterday, and it is worth repeating, the Canadian economy is fundamentally well placed for a sustained recovery.

February 26, 1992
The Budget
In summary, I think that this budget provides leadership and does what Canadians say they expect the federal government to do. But it is also true that no level of government can make the economy healthy.
The economy will only be healthy if all levels of government and all sectors of the economy work together constructively to put long-term gains ahead of shortterm interests. That is why our government, in close co-operation with the provinces, will try to strengthen the policy framework that our economic union provides for growth and future job creation.
The provinces will soon bring down their budgets. It is important that they follow a course compatible with this budget: better financial balance, lower deficits, tighter control on spending and on the tax burden. To repeat again what the Minister of Finance said, it is always the same taxpayers who pay and they deserve a break.
That is the message which Canadians gave us and we listened to it. I think the budget we tabled yesterday provides a clear answer to that message.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a lot of respect for the minister of health. I have watched him serve in many profiles for this national government over the last few years. I think that his child tax benefit plan is an interesting one and it is the beginning of an interesting debate.
The minister says they are listening to the people of Canada.
I am hearing right across this country that people want to get back to work. In the province of Quebec alone we have 600,000 entrepreneurs. This minister is the Quebec minister. I have listened to some of these people and they are not feeling confident. The unemployment numbers in the province of Quebec are high. The minister talks about children and the ability to buy snowsuits and rubber boots, and having enough food to eat. The best way to provide this is to get these people back to work. The best way for children to be looked after in terms of their health and their welfare is their mother or father having a job.
I do not see anything in this budget that is going to kick-start the entrepreneurship of this country. There are 1,700,000 entrepreneurs in this country. The government says it is way ahead of its inflation targets. It has a very low interest rate. In spite of all those things, there is a low, low confidence in this country. I believe that the Minister of Finance, without being dramatic, without going to the deficit or to the debt, should have done something to kick-start that entrepreneurial spirit that exists in this country if he wants to get people back to work again. It seems to me that that would be just as powerful a way of looking after the children of this country as the program that he is on. I am not against exploring that program, but it seems to me the dignity of a person working is equally important as that tax credit.

speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to say I appreciate the comment. It is positive. It is constructive. Maybe it is not based on the same perceptions, but I appreciate the way the member is approaching the issue.
I agree that the more we have the capacity to produce in the country, the wealth of the country will grow automatically and we will be able to do more for poor children. I totally agree with that and I agree that wealth comes first of all by working. People in the labour force who are able to get a job and to work produce wealth in the country.
However in Canada, as in any other country in the world, I would say we face today a kind of cyclical period. It happened in the 1970s and it happened at the beginning of the 1990s. I believe that my friend will agree with me that jobs are not coming. I will use the expression which is coming from French-I made a mistake this morning. I hope I will not make one this afternoon-which is spontaneous generation, which is coming so suddenly that we do have to take into account all different factors of the problem we face today. My colleague was and still is involved in the business sector. He knows very well that all those conditions are such that a few macroeconomic conditions like interest rates, dollar plays, and many other factors refer particularly to the question of restructuring of the economy and so on. When doubled with a recession as the one we face, it makes that very difficult. In Quebec, as in Ontario, it may be they are proportionally touched with problems with the recession.
February 26, 1992

Other provinces have problems too. Last week I was in British Columbia and obviously the reality is different. It is not because there are no problems. The question is the different realities in the two central provinces touched by the recession. There is no doubt in my mind that what I would call the point d'arrivee with the question of children has to be fixed with the point de depart.
The Speaker has told me that I have taken too long. I believe that what the Minister of Finance has proposed, and it may be in terms of triggering some kind of new economy, is modest in the capacity that we have to do it for small business, investors and so on.

Mr. Speaker, I heard the Minister of National Health and Welfare and Minister responsible for Quebec speak with great pride about the budget. There is another issue that is extremely important to Quebec -

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think that the Minister of Finance already commented this afternoon on the subject of the second question from the member for Rosemont. So that I can have more time for the first question, I would just point that out.
As for the first question, I do not challenge the figures given by the hon. member for Rosemont, except that I am sure he knows that the federal government transfers not only cash but also tax points for health care, at the request of Quebec, among other provinces. In 1977-78 I believe that Quebec asked the federal government to transfer tax points instead of cash, and that is exactly what has happened. If he considers the tax points transferred, he does not obtain the same result for the proportion going from 46 per cent to what it is today.
Second, the recent debate in Quebec is significant for the national health issue. All provinces share the same concern; the hon. member talked about a $1.9 billion shortfall for Quebec, but everyone agrees that 9 per cent of the gross national product for health care is enough. In other words, the health care system in Canada does not lack money, but the way it is managed must change. Mr. Cote and the other ministers agree on that. Giving Quebec $2 billion more will not necessarily relieve the overcrowded emergency wards. Funding has doubled and

February 26, 1992
The Budget
tripled in the past 10 years, but the problem has not changed. The problem is one of management and the federal government will continue to do what it has done. Of course we do not transfer money that we do not have and for the information of the member for Rosemont, Quebec does the same since it transferred responsibilities to the municipalities under the Ryan plan, as we know very well.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: The Chair, having considered the motion in amendment put forward by the hon. member for Essex-Windsor, can now rule in favour of the motion.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is an honour for me to have this opportunity to speak about the 1992 budget.
As you know, Mr. Speaker, we have a new Minister of Finance and we have been told to expect a brand new budget. I must say that, when I first looked at it, I thought that there might be something in there. Then I took a second look and realized that a coat of varnish was making everything look great. As soon as you take a good look, you can start noticing the cracks, real big cracks!

When I first saw this budget I thought just maybe there was going to be some hope for Canadians. I heard about tax breaks and I thought hallelujah. We are already so overburdened with taxes it is high time. But when I looked more closely at what was underneath this budget I realized that the tax breaks were just a bit of colouring.
When we are being hammered on the head constantly and somebody takes a chip off the hammer, we may feel a little of relief at first glance but we are still being hit on the head. It does not take away the fact that we are overtaxed. This has not helped us in any way, shape or form. What is $2 in 1992?
What we see is a budget which goes ahead and says: "In 1992 we will reduce the surtax by 1 per cent". Then when we look beneath that we find the surtax is 1 per cent but it starts July 1. Right away that makes it .5 per cent. The surtax is a tax levied on the tax that has been calculated. When we look down the line it does not mean
a whole lot, especially not for those who need it the most.
But it was a gesture and we have to allow them then-gestures. After all, this is a budget for an election year. It is a budget crafted in 1992 but nothing really happens until 1993. It is a one-year budget but with five-year benefits, so we are told.
This government is not going to be here in five years time so it is easy to project into the future. I can project all kinds of beautiful things too if I think I will not be around to answer for it.
I wanted to know, when I opened this budget document, what the government was going to do this year. Over the last few weeks we have heard about a barrage of plant closures and job losses. Over the years we have heard this government go on about competitiveness: we have to be competitive and we have to be the best.
One thing happened last week in the announced closure at the plant in St. Catharines. There was a plant that was competitive. There was a plant that made money. It is closed. Now tell me: how are we going to help those people who are faced with job loss? Is there anything at all in this budget to help these people? Absolutely nothing.
Let's talk about the farmers. What is in it for the farmers? Mum is the word, mum is the word. What is in it for the fishermen on the east coast? Absolutely nothing.
We talk about the deficit. We have heard much talk about the deficit and how this government was going to be God's gift to deficit reduction. We just have to go back to the very first years of its mandate. We had a brand new minister then. He said: "We are going to reduce the deficit. We have to reduce the deficit". The size of the annual deficit since 1986-87 has not been reduced at all.
As a matter of fact the national debt has doubled in size, and this through some of the best growth years of our economy, this despite the fact that our income taxes and all taxes have gone up at least 33 times. The average Canadian is suffering an horrendous burden in terms of taxation.
Now we are looking at bankruptcies which are reaching record levels. We are looking at unemployment which is at a record high. What is the government
February 26, 1992

predicting about unemployment? It is going to be quite normal now for our employment rate to remain above 10 per cent at least for the next two years.
What kind of nonsense is this? How can we expect to have competitive, happy and prosperous people when we are saying: "You are not going to have a job. I am sorry, we can't help you"?
Keeping in mind that the Tory text since 1984 has been expenditure control, cutting the deficit and reducing government debt, in 1990 the then Minister of Finance stated: "Our policies are working". He was making reference to the monetary policy, which by the way really helped create this made-in-Canada recession. However, as we know, the forecasts of budget deficit, interest rates, growth rates and inflation rates have consistently been wrong. Why should they be right this time?
Beginning with the February 1988 pre-election budget which was subtitled Securing Economic Renewal, the public was left to believe that renewal had been secured. "In three and a half years our economic progress has been dramatic. Our policies and initiatives have worked in building the framework for the economic success we now enjoy", stated the then finance minister.
In the following months he went on to explain: "The structural changes that we are making in the Canadian economy have strengthened the foundations for economic growth and investor confidence". Absolutely beautiful words. Where is this economy growth and investor confidence right now?
The recovery is being held back by many factors, and probably the most important one is that the Canadian consumer is afraid to spend. In any event he has very little money to spare. His confidence is badly battered, not only by the lay-offs and bankruptcies seen in any recession but also by the permanent job cuts and industrial restructuring sparked by flagging government fiscal and monetary policies.
When we hear this new finance minister speaking of restraint, we hear echoes of the other finance minister who preceded him. When he talks about failing to meet budget targets this year but achieving them in two and three years, the reverberations of prior years are very loud. Have we not all heard it before? Is it not the typical speech? "We are sorry we did not meet the targets this year, but for sure next year we are going to meet them".
The Budget
They are going to be really on target next year or five years from now or somewhere, somehow, some day they might. We might as well say that.
The Conservative record of deficit reduction is dismal. In 1985 the deficit came in at $34.6 billion what was predicted to have been $33.8 billion. They were off. The federal debt that then needed controlling was at $224 billion. Now it sits in excess of $420 billion. In 1986 the finance minister said that he would have the deficit down to $25.9 billion but it was $28.2 billion. In 1987 the deficit was $30.7 billion. In 1988 the deficit stood at $29.3 billion, and in 1989 at $28.6 billion. The deficit has gone up every year since 1987-88.
In order to hasten the recovery process, the finance minister at that time in 1989 launched what was described as an ambitious five-year fiscal plan. The finance minister was never short of plans. He mentioned this five-year deficit reduction plan in last year's budget as well. Forget the old clear and realistic medium term plan. We are now back in the business of medium term predictions with new ambitious five-year deficit reduction plans.
I go on about this only because I want to show the people that this is a lot of mumbo-jumbo and a lot of really nice words which will not produce very much. We just have to go through the list of what is in this budget today. Let me refer to one of the things that is happening. Remember how the environment was sacred to this government and it had this fabulous green plan. Let me tell the people across the way that the environment is sacred and our children will suffer because we are not being honest and we are not tackling the environment the way we should be doing.
This fabulous green plan was supposed to be a plan for five years, but the following year the Conservatives extended it to a sixth year. Now they are saying: "We really cannot afford it so we are going to cut back $75 million a year for the next two years, but we will make it up on the last three years". Come on, come on.
They talk about helping people with housing. There will be no more co-op housing. Social housing will be cut back but there will be some. Fine. We brought in the brand new idea that RRSPs could be used to purchase homes. It was a great idea. Our leader suggested it. I am

February 26, 1992
The Budget
very happy to see that they have taken it up, but why only limit it for one year? Many Canadians right now have RRSPs locked in for long terms of four or five years before they can access them. How will they be able to access these funds so they can use them this year if there is a one-year term?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Some will buy any way.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Yes, some will buy anyway and in some instances it will help.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: We hope they will buy.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
We certainly hope so. We think it was a great idea. We just wish they had extended it a little longer so that those who cannot access RRSP funds this year would be eligible to access them in the next few years.
TUming to Canada student loans, there is always a sleeper in everything they do. They give with one hand; they take away with another. They say: "We are going to allow you a bigger deduction for the fact that you are a student, but we are going to start charging interest on your Canada student loan from the day you graduate".
I do not know how many of them know students and know how difficult it is for them to get jobs. It is extremely difficult to get a job and start working the day after one graduates. For most right now it is almost impossible.
Another thing they are doing is privatizing the loans. I will give an example of a woman in my riding who came to see me not long ago. She had been left alone with two children. She decided that she did not want to live on welfare or mother's allowance. She wanted to make a life for her family. She went back to school and she got a Canada student's loan. This lady, when she finished her schooling, got a job. We have to understand that other than the Canada student's loan she has never lived off any kind of government assistance. Now it is 10 or 15 years later and she owes more in interest than she does on the original loan even though she never defaulted on her payment, not once.
The other day she came to see me and asked: "Do you think that there is some way I can get out from under this horrendous burden that seems to get worse and worse and worse?" Now her children are at an age where they have to go out and get Canada student loans.
I wonder if there is any compassion, where people who help themselves get a little help also. However, with privatization the collection people will be at her door and it will not matter that she is supporting two children and not on mother's allowance; she has to pay her loan. If she were on mother's allowance maybe she could have gone bankrupt and not even tried to pay the loan, but she did not. These kinds of insensitive actions really are deterrents to people who want to do the right thing. I would ask that you reconsider some of these methods of collecting Canada student loans. There is no doubt there are people with money who are not paying back their loans and I have no objection to you going after them. But there are many out there who are struggling and having a very, very difficult time. In that case, we should have a little compassion.
One item in the budget is reductions in grants and contributions. It all sounds so good. We do not know yet what is in that because it is going to come out with estimates tomorrow.
There are agencies eliminated and consolidated. Some of them may have been absolutely useless. Some of them could be very good. It may even lead me to believe that some of them have been eliminated because they were a little bit too good. There are two that come to mind and they happen to be led by some very capable women. I am wondering if that is something that just happened. You sometimes wonder how the minds of these financial people work.
We are going to have tighter government travel guidelines. I have no problems with that. I cannot travel first class, by the way. The only plane that flies direct to Sudbury is a 19-seater with no washroom or service. But I do pay first class prices for that flight. I wish you could do something about helping alleviate the cost of transportation for people in the outlying areas.
The communication budget cuts. Hallelujah. They are going to stop spending some of their massive advertising budgets.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Go to personal service contracts.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
I am just wondering. You are going to cut it out, but are you going to have consultants do it? How is it going to work? I have this feeling that somehow there is an election year coming and there will be some way you can go out with a massive advertising campaign.
February 26, 1992

You know, the prosperity agenda: You can do it. You can compete. You say that to the people in St. Catharines. You say that to most people and they will look at you and tell you they remember.
Tax compliance and cost recovery are great ideas, but why are you cutting back on staff in those departments? Why are you not really making those departments effective? Each one of these tax collecting people brings in more than his or her salary, yet the numbers have been reduced.
There are many people out there who have not complied with the GST. No one has been near them. No one has asked them why they have not complied. There are billions out there. Maybe if we had additional staff we could collect some of these thousands of dollars out there. I am very anxious to see something done there.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: How can people avoid paying tax?

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
You ask them. They will tell you.
Changes to withholding tax always sounds great. The government is going to allow more foreign investment in Canada. I like foreign investment. It does things for Canada, but it is only for foreigners. They are the only ones who get this benefit. Why are we not encouraging Canadians to invest in Canadian enterprises? We are giving them tax cuts but they are not half as good as this. Part of the problem with foreign investment is that all of the profits leave the country and that has been a major problem with our economy. I am of two minds about this one.
Small business financing. Hallelujah. If a small business is in trouble the government is going to allow it to borrow up to $200,000, up from $100,000.1 do not know where you people live, but I know a lot of small businesses and they have no means of borrowing up to the $100,000 even when they are in good financial positions. Do you live in Never Never Land? If a business is in trouble do you think it will be able to increase the amount of its loans to $200,000?
The child tax benefit is a beautiful package. It sounds so great. But do you realize that the family allowance cheque goes out to mothers? Every mother in this country receives the cheque directly. When the mother
The Budget
works outside the home perhaps she does not rely on that cheque coming to her directly as much as the stay-at-home mother.
Do you know that for thousands of stay-at-home mothers in this country, it is the only cheque that comes to them in their name? Is there any way at all it can be arranged in this new scheme of things that the stay-at-home mothers receive that credit directly in their hands? I think it is extremely important.
The Speaker is trying to get my attention here. I can keep going on and on. What I can say is that the government members are big on r words. I will say to the people of Canada, just remember that when we had the free trade debate they promised us jobs, jobs, jobs.
We did not get jobs, jobs, jobs so most of us are pretty sceptical now. When the GST came in they said you would love this GST. It is was going to create jobs and it was going to make us all prosperous. Nobody believed them. Nobody believes them now and nobody will believe the government is going to do anything with this budget except try to-

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we have listened with great interest to the hon. member as she described the hardship businesses are experiencing. She mentioned in particular the case of a Canadian woman who is going through hard times. Believe me, I do sympathize with the Canadian men and women who suffer hardship from time to time.
However, did the hon. member who talked a lot about the deficit, telling us it had not been reduced, tell her constituent the real reason she is suffering such hardship today and why it is increasingly difficult for government to act, that it was because we basically have our hands tied due to the mismanagement of the former Liberal government?
The hon. member talks about the deficit and tells us that this government did not reduce the deficit. The truth of the matter is that in 1984 there was a $38 billion deficit, of which $22 billion was interest to service the debt and $16 billion were cumulative operating deficits. This means that in those days the government was

February 26, 1992
The Budget
spending more than it was collecting in taxes, which created a total deficit of $38 billion.
Eight years later, in 1992, we are told that the deficit stands at $31.4 billion, with a $12 billion operating surplus, which means that the difference between $12 billion and $31.4 billion is due only to interest on the debt.
The hon. member should know that if we had a balanced budget, if revenues and expenses were the same, the deficit would now be $43.4 billion. What is worse, and the hon. member is silent on this, is that if we had kept increasing expenses at the same rate as the Liberal government did until 1984, our deficit today would be $80 billion and our debt would be $600 to $700 billion.
I ask the hon. member whether she and her party recognize, once and for all, that the deficit is indeed lower and that it is by lowering the deficit that we will again have the necessary leeway to ease the tax burden on our citizens, or does the hon. member intend to support her leader's policies-I conclude on that note -which would increase expenses, reduce revenues and add to the national debt?

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in response to the gentleman opposite, I can inform the Conservative member who just asked me a question that the Tories have not a clue how to run things. They have not the slightest inkling. They are very good at making speeches. However, when you consider we have had 33 tax increases since they came to power, during a period of prosperity the like of which we have not seen for a long time, I hardly think they have any right to say they know how to run a country.
In any case, when we come to power, we will have some terrific problems because of your poor management. In any case, we will put people first. That is how a government should be run. First, Canadians will be a lot happier and, second, we will run things very decisively.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have listened to the hon. member from Sudbury. She read a budget but I would like to ask her something. We had some comments from some other people. The President of the Canadian Manufacturers Association said that
investment in the goods producing sector will be stimulated by cuts to the tax rate on manufacturing income. He praised the government's move to let companies write off the cost of new equipment and machinery more quickly.
The hon. member talked about consumer confidence. Mel Fruitman, vice-president and research director of the Retail Council of Canada, said that the economic growth assumptions underlying the deficit forecast are creditable. His group is happy with the budget because it manages to cut both the deficit and taxes. He said they think this will help rebuild consumer confidence. Finally the Canadian Home Builders Association said they think this whole thing is a springboard to recovery.
So here are three people in the retail business who are saying this is the springboard and this indeed may bring back consumer confidence. They read the same budget. Is the hon. member telling me that the home builders, the retail council and the manufacturers association are wrong?

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
I would imagine the manufacturers are very happy at having a tax cut, and of course they would support it. But let me remind this government that there are very few manufacturers making any money these days so it really matters very little. There are also very few manufacturers.
All I can say to the member for Cambridge is that perhaps many of you, and a lot of us also, would like to continue to live in hope because otherwise we die of despair.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to compliment our co-critic of finance on her speech. During the course of her speech she talked about the Small Businesses Loans Act. This Small Businesses Loans Act, which was first passed in 1961, assists small business to access financing for investment purposes, et cetera. The amount after this budget increased from $100,000 to $200,000.
I think that is a good initiative, but there are two problems with this. Of the 1,700,000 entrepreneurs in this country, I would venture a guess that probably 95 per cent of them are not aware it exists. Second, and I would like to ask my colleague from Sudbury if she has had similar experiences, I hear from a lot of my small businesses on Queen Street, Gerard, Danforth, Pape, et cetera, that they are having a tough time maintaining
February 26, 1992

their lines of credit. Many of them are below $100,000, let alone getting an additional $100,000.
I would like to hear from my colleague and see if she has had the same experience.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
I have definitely had the same experience. I know of many people who own small businesses who have been horribly burdened by a lot of the taxes brought forward by this government. They are having a very difficult time keeping their heads above water. Many of them, by the way, are going bankrupt. That is where the bulk of the bankruptcies lie, in small business.
I tell you: You have done very little to help them because, again, as I said during my speech, if you are in trouble, no one will advance you any money. If they will not advance you up to $100,000, why would they advance you up to $200,000 when you are in trouble? I have yet to have found one small business person that is in trouble who has been able to get any kind of loan. I will tell you it is a very serious, misleading sort of statement there because that is not hope for small business. Small business needs more than just nice words. It needs concrete policies to help them get through this.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: The hon. member for North Vancouver. I would appreciate it if the hon. member would indicate to the Chair if he is splitting his time with another colleague.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
That was the first thing I was going to mention, Mr. Speaker. With your consent, I will split my time in order that more speakers may have an opportunity to be heard in this debate.
My comments will be in a slightly different vein from what we have been listening to today, I think perhaps much more philosophical than some of the comments.
I have been a participant and have listened to and watched this kind of debate for something like 13 years. I think some of the opposition speeches I have heard are quite good, as a matter of fact well done. We did the same speeches between 1980 and 1984 with about the same results in terms of affecting government policy.
There is one question that does not seem to be asked here. I have yet to hear a speaker even mention the
The Budget
subject and perhaps it is the most important subject facing this country and this House of Commons today. I do not hear it being mentioned on the government benches particularly nor on the opposition benches. That question simply is: Can we afford it?
What can we afford and what can we not afford? With a really creative budget, if we were to gather together all of the ideas expressed by the opposition, put them together, the amount of spending would be absolutely massive and massive spending at this time is the last thing this country needs.
What people seem to forget is that the whole world is in a restructuring mode. The economic world order is in a process of changing radically. I suspect it is the largest change that has taken place in economics in the world since the industrial revolution. If that is going on, then I will forgive my own government for not being able to go against the trend of the new economic world order, but I would suggest to all Canadians that they consider very carefully what is taking place throughout the world, which means that an individual government of any country, and you could look at them all, really has little to say or can influence the total world significantly today. In John Donne's words: "We are not an island unto ourselves" and that bell is tolling for all countries and all economic orders in the world. We have seen some of it in eastern Europe. We are certainly seeing a restructuring taking place in the United States, North America, Central America, throughout the world. Things are changing and changing radically.
I cannot agree to massive spending in an attempt to go against world trends. To use another analogy, I am not really sure that massive spending would have helped the Luddites in the economic revolution that took place with industrialization at all. Massive spending is not the answer. Time, perhaps, will help, doing what you can to help individuals and people, but note the qualifier: doing what you can. I personally, and I think a great many Canadians, do not believe that you can solve problems by throwing massive amounts of money at them. If you would like an example, let us talk about Atlantic Canada and the maritimes. Certainly over the last few generations, massive amounts of money have been thrown at Atlantic Canada and look at the results; not very much.

February 26, 1992
The Budget
We have a new world economic order, the greatest structuring since the time of the industrial revolution. That brings me then to the solutions being offered. Let us deal with all parties. I am attempting to be pragmatic and fair. If I look at the Liberals, all I have to do is look at their record and listen to their speeches during this debate. Obviously they would go back to what they did so successfully and for so long, spending massive amounts of money, building up the national debt, paying no attention to the fact that their grandchildren and mine will still have debts to pay off as a result.
If you look at the New Democratic Party, it would do even more. We have evidence of that already in the present NDP government of Ontario. Do not forget a $10 billion deficit for the province of Ontario will grow and will be there for some time. If that is the economic policy of the New Democratic Party, as much as it wants to help people, as much as it feels that everyone should be helped, somebody has to pay for it.
That is one of the things I note in this House that people tend to forget. Who is supposed to pay these bills and how are they going to be paid? There is little thought given to that. I suppose the Canadian public does not give that much too it as well.
Let me talk briefly in terms of our own party. I do not particularly like our present budget if you would like to know. I think 1 per cent cuts, things like 5 per cent off cabinet ministers' salaries, travel restrictions where you cannot fly first class-I have not found a first-class flight in a year anyway-are cosmetic. I do not think they were needed there and I think they are somewhat dishonest as well. I wish we did not have them there.
However, over all, the Minister of Finance has done a good job with what he had to work with and with the times in which he is preparing a budget. We are into a situation where the best thing we can do is try to hold our own, not increase spending, and sincerely hope that the world turns around and starts recovering. I doubt if there is going to be any major recovery in Canada until we see the world straightening itself out. There is little evidence of that at the moment.
I do not mean to be depressing about the whole subject, but I also do not believe that any Canadian government is alone. We are part of the world and we survive by being world traders. The more world trade we can do, the better off we are.
I should also mention that other party that perhaps is the one that is talked about most these days, and that is the Reform Party. We have the huge spenders, the NDP. We have the spenders, the Liberals. We have the Conservatives and, for a change, that name means something, attempting to conserve, attempting to be conservative. And then you have the Reformers. If we can believe what they say, they would cut and slash throughout government. It is almost a situation of throwing the baby out with the bath water because they would disrupt this country and the governing of this country to such an extent that it would take years to recover from it.
I just lost another group of friends.
Remember, in government operations we have done a couple of good things over the last few years. It has not been as good as I would have liked, but we have turned an additional government operations deficit of $16 billion around to a surplus of $13 billion. That is pretty good action in terms of government operations. A lot more of them could and should perhaps be cut down.
Just remember, every dollar this or any government spends when it is added to the deficit means another dollar for your grandchildren to have to pay. Why were we sent here? We were sent to this place to attempt to do the best we can for the people we represent. Obviously, there is a difference in viewpoint between the three parties as to what we feel is the best thing to do.
We seem to have forgotten that the initial purpose was to do the best we can for this country, but to do it in a prudent way. We are in a situation where our spending must be cut back. Spending is being cut back. We are preparing for a situation-

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Order, please. I invite the hon. member to end his speech, please.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: To conclude his remarks in five seconds. In any event these are some of the things. I wish every member would think about them and realize we cannot go on spending if we hope to have a country for the future.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first I want to say that I agree with my hon. friend from Vancouver when he describes the reduction in cabinet salaries and the abolition of first-class air travel for MPs as cosmetic. I agree with him. I think it is
February 26, 1992

tokenism. I do not think the government will score any Brownie points with that budget initiative.
I want to get on to something else. My hon. friend from Vancouver was talking about the global changes, the restructuring of the world economy. It is true. There is a major change going on. It is hard to say where it is all going to end. It is hard to say where Canada is going to wind up in this major world-wide restructuring that is going on.
What I find rather passing strange, when it comes to the budget and when you take into account the restructuring of the world economy, is this government's decision to abolish the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada. To me, it makes no sense. It seems to me that at the very time when there is this major alteration in the world economy, and where a lot of us really do not know where we are going, it is sort of like travelling in the dark, at the very time when we need independent research and independent advice from independent bodies like the Science Council of Canada, the Economic Council of Canada, what does this government do? It abolishes them. It does not seem to make any sense.
There is no way it is going to do without some kind of consultation, without some kind of independent research. It seems to me that there will be no saving to the taxpayer. The government will have to go to independent or rather private think-tanks like, for example, the Fraser Institute which is located in his home city.
I ask the hon. member, does it make any sense to abolish these advisory bodies? It does not to me.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
I have two points in regard to the hon. member's comments. The first point is this. There are parallel organizations to both the Economic Council and to the Science Council. As a matter of fact, most of the work now that the Science Council used to do is being done by an advisory group.
I come back to my initial and original point and would re-emphasize it again. They would be nice, yes. Can we afford it? I wish that question would be asked more often by more people around this place. Can we afford it?
The Budget
Lots of things are nice.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Can you afford not to be without it?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Resuming debate. The hon. member for Beauce, who has 10 minutes.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to say a few words about the budget. There has been a lot of comment, and editorial writers across Canada, both anglophones and francophones, expressed a lively interests this morning in the budget. I think on the whole their reaction was positive.
Yesterday, the finance minister brought down a budget that apparently sent a signal not only to the federal apparatus but to all other levels of government, including the provincial government, the municipal government and school boards across Quebec.
I visit my riding regularly, and for many months I have been meeting hundreds of people, both in my riding offices and at special events. Every time people said that governments-and when they spoke to me they meant the federal government-should cut spending and stop using the credit system they have used for 25 years.
Incidentally in early January I wrote to the Minister of Finance and told him what my constituents had said, that people were starting to have enough and were irritated to see how governments were acting. I also told him that our Quebec caucus committee on spending cuts had come up with 32 points where government spending could be cut.
Of course the government apparatus had grown fat over the years, thanks to our predecessors, and the annual deficit was out of control. When we took power in 1984 we had an accumulated debt of over $220 billion and interest rates started to climb. As a result, today we have a national debt of more than $400 billion and an annual deficit that we reduced from $38 billion to about $30.5 billion. Interest rates were steadily going up and inflation was not under control.

February 26, 1992
The Budget
Today we have good news. I think that it is because of previous budgets that clearly told the public that it had to make sacrifices. As part of our economic plan, we are still trying to lower the rate of inflation.
I remember that in 1982 when I was a businessman in Beauce inflation was 13.5 per cent. Today we have reached a record 1.6 per cent, the lowest since March 1971, 21 years ago. Since our government's restrictive policies brought inflation under control and interest rates are down, I think that with a budget like the one we presented we can do good things for the people not only in Beauce but in Quebec and in Canada.
On behalf of my constituents in Beauce, I told the Minister of Finance that we had to cut in several areas. I listed them and it was publicized in Beauce. People know my position on the budget presented yesterday. I must say that our finance minister listened to his MPs, who listened to the people.
Today The Budget Papers show that drastic measures have been taken. We want to make cuts in many places: grants, contributions and other programs. On page 84, we read: "Reflecting the need to make the deficit reduction and expenditure restraint thrusts as broad as feasible, a wide spectrum of grants and contributions will be reduced. The savings will be $170 million in 1992-93, $71 million in 1993-94". People will have an opportunity to read it. Copies are available in our constituencies. All these cuts will be made so that we can have funds for new programs to stimulate employment.
We are eliminating the waste due to overlapping and duplication in the federal administration. The government machine was simply too big. We are eliminating the waste due to duplication with the private sector. There is the possibility of strengthening particular sectors by combining related organizations and their functions and the need to postpone desirable initiatives that the government cannot afford to finance right now. We are continuing to privatize commercial activities that no longer serve the needs of public policy.
Canadians clearly indicated that they want the government to live within its means. They want a smaller burden imposed on them by the public sector. It has been
mentioned that the salary of the Prime Minister and his ministers was cut by 5 per cent. This is not where the emphasis should be put. We have streamlined federal administration by cutting 46 institutes, commissions, international centres, boards, monitoring agencies and advisory committees. There are many. The axe fell on 46 of them yesterday at midnight. The equivalent of these corporations is easily found within the Department of Science and Technology where basically the same work is done.
Projects such as the Canadian Race Relations Foundation and the Canadian Heritage Languages Institute are postponed. We will merge or combine some other corporations or other groups to save money. We will privatize corporations. We will cut $2.2 billion in National Defence.
I said earlier that we have been living on credit for 25 years. We have created an excessively heavy governmental apparatus. It took a few years to streamline this apparatus, because we had to get to know the organization inside out.
The 1992 budget will cut spending by $1 billion next year and by $7 billion over the next five years. We have had to take measures that were not always popular. In the past seven years, we have made a tremendous effort to cut public spending, but I think the finance minister has now come up with the kind of proposals Canadians were waiting for.
The expenditure control plan introduced in the 1990 budget and extended by last year's budget will be broadened and deepened. Defence spending, as I said before, will be cut by a total of $2.2 billion. Non-wage operating budgets of federal departments will be cut by 3 per cent. That is a lot of money. This will save $150 million next year and $800 million over a five-year period.
First-class travel for members of Parliament, senators and senior public servants, already subject to restrictions, will be eliminated altogether. It does not make sense to have senior officials flying around the world at great expense. One senior official does not matter that much, but when you have 1,000 across the country running up this kind of expenses it is time to pull the plug.
February 26, 1992

The growth in spending by Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation on social housing will be held to an average of 3 per cent per year. The government will also set aside funds to review the tax treatment of family budgets. This is important, but unfortunately I do not have enough time to expand. I do know a number of useful initiatives have been taken and that my constituents will be very pleased. Of course there are a number of so-called tax experts and economists who make sweeping statements and say that ministers' salaries should be cut by 5 per cent. lire budget does more than that.
I prefer to listen to what was said by the economists who came out yesterday in support of the government. There is a reference to "Wilson's iron hand in Mazan-kowski's velvet glove" in Alain Dubuc's editorial in La Presse this morning. "Without necessarily being a reason to rejoice, the budget brought down yesterday afternoon will probably be the least unpopular Tory budget we have seen so far, not only because it does not hurt as much, but because for the first time the Tories have managed to square the circle; in other words, reduce the deficit and taxes simultaneously".
No tax increases, no increases in income tax, and at the same time we reduce the deficit. That is why I think we should support what the Minister of Finance is trying to do. I think that each department will go ahead and implement these decisions, decisions based on the recommendations members have made to the Minister of Finance who has listened to them. We have pleaded the good cause on behalf of our constituents. The people from Beauce will no doubt be happy to know that this budget contains no tax increases but does contain spending cuts.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask my colleague to comment on two aspects of the budget.
First, he commented about listening to his constituents and in the budget the finance minister talked about consulting with Canadians, business, labour, voluntary and social sectors, students, managers and farmers.
The finance minister also met with the provincial premiers. I know that the premier of Ontario and the premier of Alberta had asked for RRSPs to be used as
The Budget
down payments on homes. The finance minister for Quebec had asked for controls on government deficit. The Nova Scotia premier asked for a reduction in tax levels and the premier of Newfoundland asked for restrained government spending. These things were in the budget.
I would like him to comment on whether he believes that the finance minister listened.
The second comment was about how the finance minister was able to reallocate spending. The example is the new child tax benefit in The Budget Papers. The cost to do that particular program when it is mature is about $300 million.
However, the finance minister by the equal tax treatment of common law couples and married couples is able to save $280 million, which basically pays for the program. Is the member impressed with the finance minister's ability to reallocate spending?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would say that the steps taken by the Minister of Finance and this government are incentives. This reallocation of spending and the ensuing cuts will do a world of good to our balance sheet a year from now. Over time I am sure this will, as my hon. colleague mentioned, give us the tools we need to keep working at creating jobs. It is clear that this cannot be done overnight, but by cutting spending we bring the deficit under control and foster low interest rates which make borrowing quite affordable for the Canadian people as well as a controlled rate of inflation. With control there is more money available for social programs.
I think the social programs listed in the 1992 budget speech are far-reaching, national programs that will benefit the Canadian people. The effects will be felt in a year or two. We could have let the deficit keep on increasing as the previous government did. The Liberals never cut expenditures during the 22 years they were in power, pleasing everybody, creating programs, spending money and helping friends. That is the role they played, but now we figure that people have had it with that kind of useless spending.
Streamlining will improve budget analysis and their application to direct job creation. I know that the incentives concerning our manufacturers contained in

The Budget
this budget will promote job creation in the long run. We must first maintain the jobs that are there. That is very important. Were the recession affecting only Canada there might be an easier way out, but it is world-wide. If every government in the world took steps, and particularly those in our country-I urge my provincial colleagues, the councillors and mayors at the municipal level and the school board administrators to follow our lead and to cut spending, cut surpluses and streamline- we would all be better off.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to join in the debate on a very important budget at a very important time in our country's development. Every budget gives us a chance not only to comment on what the Minister of Finance has to say, but also to reflect upon the situation in the country.
I would like to address the question of the structure of the economy and the failure of this budget to address it. In the last three years, partially as a result of the free trade agreement and partially the result of a number of structural changes in the Canadian economy, the Canadian economy has been unable to create the wealth to sustain government activity. At the same time the strategy of this government has been to reinforce the failure of the private sector to create wealth, and the fact it is has only created debt itself.
We come into this budget with the reality that we have been unable to find ourselves with a presentation since the formation of this government of under $30 billion a year. The annual debt and an accumulated debt are now estimated to be in the neighbourhood of $450 billion. It does not take a genius to figure out that although it limits the government's actions every year there have to be voices in the House to say that some people are responsible for this. The responsibility of the government is to make sure that Canadians are better looked after in some changes in the way it has structured this economy and in the way it has structured this budget.
It is without apology that I say that this budget is another failure of this government to respond to the great economic malaise we find ourselves in, in the hope that people will begin to listen, to understand that other
countries have found other strategies out of recessions such as this. In our history since the industrialization of Canada, whenever our government has chosen to sit back and to do nothing in times of economic crisis, the recession or the depression has only worsened. The Keynesian strategy of using capital works and public consumption to gear up the economy is one which has been successful one decade after another.
Many times people respond to me by saying that is just another cliche, that is just another Liberal position. I would like to point out that one of the major differences between the Canadian economy and the American economy is that the Americans can rely on private consumption to pull themselves out of a recession or out of a depression. In markets in excess of 250 million people, there are those who can spend their way out. The production facilities are there and so on. The logic of the American economy is to use private consumption to generate enough demand which, in turn, begins the cycle again.
In Canada, with our weak markets, our small markets, the fact that most production takes place offshore, either elsewhere in North America, in Asia or in Europe, means that the way we generate wealth in this country is entirely different. The failure of this budget to deal, first of all, with the creation of wealth is astounding. Second, the failure of this budget to deal with the consequences of not having wealth is also outstanding.
The fact that we have 10 per cent unemployment accepted as a structural reality in the Canadian economy, in this budget, is amazing. The fact that we have a UI system which translates into people being taken off UI and put on to provincial and municipal welfare systems also undermines the stability of the economy and reinforces the reality of the 10 per cent figure for unemployment which is in fact much higher.
Depending on whose figures we want to use, we have somewhere between two million to 2.5 million Canadians out of work and living either on welfare or on UI and unable to find even a temporary position, let alone full-time successful employment.
I was happy to see in this budget the government wanting to deal with a couple of questions of pressing concern in social policy. It has been a while since we have had an initiative on this government's part on the social policy front. I think it is a beginning with the question of
February 26, 1992

child poverty which should be commended and should be supported. As I will note throughout my speech today, that is not sufficient in its approach, but nevertheless the minister should be congratulated on combining a white paper on the reform of the child welfare system or the child support system, along with the economic statements. I hope that the white paper provides an opportunity for the House to continue this discussion and also to have extensive discussions and consultations with groups outside Parliament.
In dealing with the question of poverty in this country, which this budget seeks to address, we have heard through one report after another of the crisis among children in poverty. This government seeks to address it by answering one of the most important components of the problem-cash in low income families. By targeting children in low income families, it helps to begin the process by providing the resources needed to look after the basics.
In the history of North American social policy, that is considered to be but one component of a multi-pronged strategy needed to answer the question of child poverty. Up to the arrival of this particular government, in the history of Canada, dating back to the 1930s, we saw a series of initiatives to deal with child poverty which have been severely undermined in the past eight years. Here I am referring, for example, to questions of food.
For the first time since the depression, we have to deal with the reality of finding food for children, either in the schools or in the food banks. It has been largely a voluntary effort and we support the voluntary organizations such as Winnipeg Harvest which have been delivering food to children for the past couple of years, but we also have to deal with the reality that these organizations need support. It has been recognized in our major urban centres of Winnipeg, Vancouver, Toronto and now Montreal that as of September publicly funded food programs will be needed in the schools. This particular budget is silent on the needs to expand the Canada assistance program to make sure children have food.
Second, one of the foundations in social policy for addressing questions of child poverty is that of the adequate provision of housing. We have, for many years, tried to put on the market in large and small centres, but
The Budget
particularly in large centres in Canada, as many housing units as possible so that children have a place to go to in the evening, their families have a place to sleep, all these basics which have been taken for granted.
We find in this budget, once again, a cutback in social housing. More astoundingly we find the elimination of the co-operative housing program which was an excellent process for combining the resources of individuals with the resources of government to build a significant number of units to which low income families have had access. I am very sorry to see the demise of this program. When you juxtapose it to the initiative on child benefits, you see that on the one hand the government has taken away support systems while the other hand it is putting forward the promise of other benefits.
A third area in which looking after children is very important is the area of health care. We have long used Canada's national health care system to ensure both preventive medicine as well as responsive medicine for children is available in every community. The tremendous cutbacks in transfer payments to the provinces are having a devastating effect on the health care system. This is recognized by members on all sides of this House and it has been recognized by every provincial government. We need further support for the medicare system so the basic health needs of children can be addressed.
In addition, we have used education as the major source of mobility for children. We now find that because of the offloading of costs related to changes in the UI programming and transfer payments, more and more of the problems related to inner city schooling, for example, have been put on school boards which can no longer afford the programs to support children from poor families. They can no longer support, for example, English language or French language training for new Canadians.
This means that poverty becomes a more permanent condition in our inner cities because school boards and municipalities cannot respond to the needs. They cannot respond to the needs because the taxpayer at the local level has been overburdened. That is because the province has to offload costs to protect their tax base. The province has to offload because the federal government has cut back so much.

The Budget
We find, if we look at the basics of education, health care, housing and food, the government has walked away from four of the most essential ingredients in the support of children in our society.
I would like to take a minute to point out that one of the great gaps in this budget is dealing with aboriginal children. As we all know, we deal with aboriginal youth, particularly on reserves but also in Canada's larger cities. Very few aboriginal families are captured by the tax system and their support systems are very important.
This budget is silent on the question of aboriginal development, except to note the cutback in excess of $130 million to organizations delivering services such as child welfare, education and health care.
We find that before we discuss the actual child benefits package, we had better be sure that we understand the exact implications of the total strategy of this government. It has so undermined the life of children in this country that it now has to bring together a package which only begins to address the problems it has created for itself.
The program as outlined by the white paper attached to the budget has been welcomed by many of the groups involved with poverty and developing public policy on poverty for the past decade. In this context, the government has developed some good-will among groups which have been long seeking some income support for low income families.
The question becomes: Where does one find the money? The immediate response of this government is to argue that through the end of universality, one will make moneys available to low income families. The spectre is raised many times-it was raised by the minister today in Question Period-of why Canadian taxpayers should support a family where the income earned is $250,000.
That is not the question to be addressed. The question to be addressed is how does the ordinary Canadian working family maintain support for their children? The question does not become the traditional argument of targeting versus universality, but how does one reach out and make sure that families which need support are kept within the framework of social policy and not shunted aside?
When one begins to set aside that rhetoric of the initial position in the white paper and in the tax papers and begins to look at it more concretely, one finds that Canadians are being asked to pay a very, very high price for having the child tax benefit program.
It is only for families whose income rises above $40,000 that the benefit is marginal in this new system. Members should not forget that this is the big shift that no one wants .to talk about. We are no longer talking about individual incomes, we are talking about family incomes.
The price that we are paying for the end of universality is marginal to the healthiness of the individual families that we are trying to reach.
For example, if two people are working in a family and they are both earning a very modest $25,000 a year for a total of $50,000 and if they have two children, the benefits now are going to be about $4 a month. Four dollars a month is marginal in improving the situation of your children.
As we review this budget we should be careful to make sure that Canadians understand that this package is being put together with a little bit of sleight of hand.
For many families earning $40,000, $50,000 or $55,000 a year-do not forget that according to StatsCanada, the average family income is $51,600-when you have thresholds in which you begin to decline the benefits, a lot of the benefits decline at $40,000 and also do not forget that this is indexed the same way that the pensions now are at 3 per cent each year. Every three years, you lose 10 per cent from the thresholds, you find very quickly that the average Canadian family will have access to minimal or no benefits under this.
