February 26, 1992

In the meantime the government has presented a package in which each of the documents is presenting a slightly different figure as to what it is. Following the presentation of the budget, the benefits for a working couple with two children at the threshold level of $30,000 are to be about $44 in favour of these families; at $40,000, $44 in favour of these families; and then an anomaly: it is slightly more at $50,000 and drops off dramatically right after that.
I want to point out that many Canadian families in large metropolitan areas will assume when a government talks about targeting and helping out working families that it recognizes that the tax burden put upon those families in the last seven years has been very difficult for them to manage.
There have been estimates from independent agencies lately that the additional tax burden put on Canadian families is somewhere between $1,000 and $1,200. We have seen higher figures, but let us use the lower figure. Well, that is a tremendous burden when the return appears to be about $44 per year.
As we examine this proposal more closely, we will see that we must ask Canadians whether or not these benefits are worth it. I am sure the minister would be interested in examining these figures more closely in the weeks to come.
We welcome the beginning of the discussion on one of the most central issues in social policy'. That is how we look after our children. We are not particularly happy to see that. We are beginning to pit one child against another.
Family income levels now become an issue as to whether a child is helped. Families with marginal incomes in metropolitan areas are deemed to be too wealthy to be helped and others to be poor enough to be helped. This segmentation in social policy within communities and neighbourhoods in the past has led to devastation and a decline in support for social programs.
This party calls upon the government not to move ahead with this budget but in fact to remove it, and particularly to set up the white paper for extensive consultation so that we may all take a better look at this child benefits package as presented in the budget.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was listening carefully to my hon. friend opposite. I was
The Budget
surprised that he would attack a program which is so fundamentally sound in its basic structure. It opens the delivery of social programs in Canada so that they are available universally to everyone, but they are delivered through the tax system based on income.
Surely he does not expect in any way that people who earn $100,000 or $200,000 a year or even more, should be getting a family allowance. We have this extraordinarily complicated system of giving out money, taking it back, giving it to one person and taking it from another person in the same family.
Can he tell me what he would propose doing to make the system simpler, more fair, and universally accessible to all families?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome the question from the member for Calgary North and the question of who
has access to the money.
One of the support systems we have quietly provided for Canadian families is to provide a cheque each month for several million women, although the amount has been very modest. In fact, using the figures out of the budget it is estimated that 600,000 women probably will not receive a cheque any more.
The question of who receives the cheque is very interesting. So far the white paper is silent on that. I would be interested to see how the Department of Finance, as it develops this concept of family income, which will be the first time that it has really been developed, decides who actually gets the cheque.
I speak advisedly here, not as an expert, but the sum appears to be a minimum of $100 a month, perhaps more. Then that does begin to affect the family expenditure patterns. It will be interesting to see exactly how we should all work together to make sure that the moneys are allocated properly. It is not a question of having the so-called little bit of money on the side, but in fact it is now a major amount of money to be suggested here.
The question of how to proceed at this point is, of course, the most interesting one facing us in the House. We welcome the opportunity to listen to people and to develop the policies as the Parliament of Canada and to see which direction to go in.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the member for Winnipeg-St. James for the question.
In the Manitoba area it is estimated that there are at least 45,000 unemployed and that represents only those who are captured by the UI system. As my colleague well knows, that excludes aboriginal people whose figures are not even included.
The number of people not participating in the labour force in Winnipeg alone is probably 50,000. In Manitoba I would estimate it to be 75,000 to 80,000 people.
As those people get left behind and get left out of the UI training process and have no access to other training, the issue becomes absolutely critical that we find a way to put people back to work.
I was reminded by another colleague that in looking at the total amount of moneys we spend in this country on welfare and UI pay-outs, we would have a work force of considerable proportion if we could just understand that historically we put these peole to work.
Taking the strategy this year that for some reason the less work that we have for these people to do the better off we are going to be is an absolutely absurd strategy. We must take those funds available to us, recognizing that the money is already going out each week-

speechtext:
If it is as my colleague says, $30 billion that means we have roughly $600 million going out each week which just disappears into the system.
There are no jobs, no hopes, no training. How do the young people at the age of 18 put themselves in a situation where they can go to school, can find jobs in the summer and can get a start? Those who are 18 and are not inclined for whatever reason to go to school, what do they do for the next decade?
We are going to wake up here at the turn of the century and, instead of having these glorious speeches about the future of the country, we are going to be trying to explain to a number of people under the age of 40 why we could not figure out what to do with them.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have the opportunity of speaking in this very important debate. I will be brief as I wish to share my time with the hon. member for Hochelaga-Maison-neuve.
First of all, let me say that the budget presented by my colleague, the hon. Minister of Finance, is both a caucus budget and one which clearly responds to the needs of people, particularly the needs of families with children.
As chairman of our caucus committee on family issues, I am very pleased with this. In fact I am delighted that the minister has responded in a very significant way to the recommendations that I and some 30 of my colleagues have worked on over the last two years. In this regard, I would like to thank most sincerely all of my colleagues who have worked to prepare these proposals.
In fact, I would go so far as to say that this effort to bring about one of the most revolutionary changes in the way we deliver social programs is a near perfect example of what can be accomplished when a truly national party is given the responsibility for governing our country.
These proposals received support within our caucus from British Columbia, Alberta of course, all through the west and into Ontario. The enthusiasm and support that my colleagues in Quebec offered was truly heartwarming and I want to offer a very sincere thank you to them.

speechtext:

February 26, 1992

I wish that everyone in Alberta could understand at the most basic level of love of family and concern for children just how much Quebecers are like Albertans, and vice versa. We would have no trouble in keeping this country together if we could communicate on this basic level. To my colleagues in Quebec, I extend my warmest thanks.
The efforts of our caucus committee were also strongly supported by our colleagues in Atlantic Canada. They, too, understand that all Canadians want a tax system to be fair, simple and supportive of families and traditional values.
I extend to all of my colleagues my sincere thanks, but most of all I would like to thank our leader, the right hon. Prime Minister, for the direction and encouragement he has given us and the Minister of Finance and the Minister of National Health and Welfare for their support and their willingness to take on a reluctant bureaucracy.
Our Prime Minister and the cabinet have clearly shown through this budget that they care about the aspirations of all Canadians.
The new integrated child tax benefit may be the most dramatic change in so far as it changes the way social programs are delivered.
But the other items, such as the new rule allowing RRSPs to be used for home purchases, the general tax reduction, the supplement for low income working families with children, and the introduction of fairness between married and common law couples are all clear indications that this government and this minister care about families, particularly families with children.
The average person in Canada has veiy simple aspirations. He or she wants to grow up to be a healthy, productive and happy adult, get a job, get married, buy a house, raise children, and eventually retire in reasonable comfort and watch the children go through the same cycle. I know because I am at the beginning of that watching cycle. I care very much about the future of my children and my grandchildren.
This budget speaks forcefully to these good citizens who form the backbone of our society. First of all, it says very simply and clearly that the government is no longer
The Budget
going to tax marriage and quite rightly so. People should not be taxed on their lifestyles.
Under the existing system married couples sometimes get a better deal than common-law couples. But common-law couples, particularly those with children, more often get tax breaks that are not available to married couples. These inconsistencies will come to an end with the implementation of this budget.
There are many initiatives in this budget that will encourage investment and create jobs. Perhaps the most important is that the manufacturing and processing income tax rate will be reduced in two steps from 23 per cent to 21 per cent. Along with this, the capital cost allowance for manufacturing and processing machinery will be improved by 5 per cent and the withholding tax rate on direct dividends will be reduced to 5 per cent.
Tax incentives for research and development will be increased by $230 million. Lower interest rates will be made available to small businesses and farmers who are in difficulty and small business loan limits will be doubled from $100,000 to $200,000.
All of these and other actions will improve the health and the investment climate in the business sector. Five hundred thousand new jobs should result.
As I said earlier, virtually everyone wants to own their own home. The recently announced reduction of the down payment required for a home, plus the budget initiative allowing anyone buying a home to take $20,000 from RRSPs, will put home ownership within the reach of many thousands of Canadians who could not previously afford it.
I would like to note here for our viewers and those listening at home that anyone who does not have a 1991 or earlier RRSP to use in this way and who is contemplating buying a house before the end of the year, has only two days in which to make an RRSP contribution. If he or she makes such a contribution, it should be in the form of short term, say 30 to 90 day notes, so that it can be cashed in before this opportunity expires.
Despite the fact that this option is only available for a short time, I am very pleased that our Minister of Finance has developed such a simple and safe plan to help use RRSPs to get people into their own homes

The Budget
while at the same time boost the home construction industry and preserve the value and purpose of RRSPs.
The real centrepiece for families in this budget is Canada's new integrated child tax benefit. This represents a totally new approach to the delivery of our basic social programs. The present system is a jumble of contradictions and complicated taxback systems that are based on an outmoded, flat rate concept of universality. This new proposal says that the child tax benefit should be paid through the tax system, that it should be based on income, and that it should be universally available to everyone. This is the proper form of universality. People earning $100,000 this year do not get it, but if their income drops to $20,000 next year they get it.
I am pleased that the Minister of Finance has decided to base the child tax benefit on family income. This combined with his decision to eliminate the difference between married and common law couples will mean that the tax system will be much fairer, and when it comes to taxes fairness is the key to their acceptability.
The future health of our nation is based on our ability to raise children to be physically and psychologically healthy and productive adults. This is the only real insurance that we have for the sustainability of our society.
I am very pleased therefore that the Minister of Finance and the Minister of National Health and Welfare have developed this child tax benefit and that they have included in it a supplement for low income working families, with children. The supplement, which may be up to $500 will assist those families who may not have access to subsidized child care to get out from under the welfare trap. As it reduces with increasing income it is consistent with the over-all model of delivering social support that is reduced as income levels improve.
There are many other ways in which the Minister of Finance and the Prime Minister have shown that they care about the circumstances and aspirations of Canadians and that they listen to their caucus colleagues who bring these concerns and advice to them.
I could list a few in these last minutes I have to speak: assisting Canadians with disabilities; improving their medical expense deductions; giving them education credits; recognizing disability pensions as earned income; and
such other things for the environment we live in as removing taxes from ethanol and gasoline mixtures; helping students, very much another family issue, by increasing their education credits; and making retirement plans more flexible. All these things show a sense of caring and concern for Canadians. Cutting the government's own expenditures has been its most important action because in this way we can afford to do all of this without increasing the deficit.

speechtext:

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE

February 26, 1992

he might understand. Because of that, I would say the change has only been agreed upon in the last couple of months and it takes a good year to take something this complex and implement it. subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am honoured to participate in this debate on the 1992 budget. I would like to highlight a few points for the benefit of my constituents in Hochelaga-Maison-neuve.
I am thrilled with the improved taxation for families and I must congratulate my colleague from Calgary North for his efforts and hard work. We will simplify, streamline and improve the assistance we give to 2.9 million families and 2.3 million children in Quebec. Nationally benefits will increase by 400 million dollars a year.
National Health and Welfare Canada has proposed, in a white paper, the new integrated child tax benefit. Canadians know that our future prosperity and well-being depend on our children. Undoubtedly, according to international standards, Canadian children are in very good health and receive good care and education.
Of course parents are chiefly responsible for seeing to the needs of their children, as we have long recognized through our public programs such as family allowances and the assistance provided in our tax system. Those programs will be totally restructured and substantially enriched. The actual patchwork of federal measures made up of three different child benefit programs-family allowances, child tax credit and refundable child tax credit-will be replaced by one single monthly benefit for children under 18.
The new benefit will be as much as $144 per month per child for a total of $1,733 a year. It will also include a new eamed-income supplement of up to $500. This benefit will represent a supplementary assistance for working low to middle-income families.
Furthermore benefits will be based on family income rather than personal income and that improves the fairness of this new program. A single monthly benefit is

The Budget
more simple, more efficient and better adapted to the needs of a family than the actual system which sometimes has the families wait for many months before they get a payment.
The budget also provides assistance to families by changing the deduction for child care expenses. The maximum child care expense deduction will be increased by $1,000 to $5,000 for each child under age seven and to $3,000 for other eligible children.
We will make it easier to own property, by letting Quebec families use funds already invested in their RRSPs. Individuals will be able to use up to $20,000. This means that if there are two people in a family, a husband and a wife, and they each have $20,000, they can invest $40,000 in this home and in the next 10 years they will be able to save $4,000 annually to put back into their fund. This means that they can repay in 10 years, instead of 15, the $40,000 previously invested in a registered retirement savings plan and used to buy or build a house. This measure, which takes effect immediately and will apply until March 1, 1993, will make it easier to buy a house and be a big boost to the economy. Those who take advantage of it will have 15 years to repay the amount withdrawn from their RRSR As I just told you, they can also do so in 10 years.
The Home Buyers' Plan will help Canadians take advantage of mortgage rates that are now lower than ever, as well as of moderate prices for homes. It will also help buyers benefit from the recently announced reduction in the down payment required for a CMHC-insured mortgage.
This new plan will contribute to renewed growth in the housing sector this year. According to the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, housing starts should increase 15 per cent this year. The real estate industry will benefit from the improved economic climate and lower interest rates. Homes have never been so affordable in the past 10 years, except for a brief period in 1985.
As for providing greater assistance to the disabled, new measures improve the help given to some 42,000 handicapped people in Quebec in order to reduce the disincentives to work that hold them back. The list of expenses eligible for the medical expenses tax credit will be expanded, as will the list of expenses eligible for the
tax deduction for modifications by businesses to buildings and devices to assist Canadians with disabilities.
Furthermore, the education tax credit will now be made available to disabled individuals who attend postsecondary educational institutions on a part-time basis, while the definition of earned income for the purposes of pensions will be expanded.
With the increase in education credit, the budget provides additional tax relief to students, who are our most important resource. The amount on which the education credit is calculated will be increased from $60 to $80 per month of full-time study, starting with the 1992 fiscal year. The limit on the total amount of tuition fees and education credits which can be transferred to another taxpayer will be raised from $600 to $680.
The personal income surtax will be reduced. All 4.7 million Quebec taxpayers will benefit as a result of the reduction in the general surtax. It will drop from 5 per cent of basic tax to 4 per cent on July 1,1992, and to 3 per cent on January 1, 1993. This will increase Canadians' after-tax income by $500 million in 1992-93, and by more than $1.2 billion per year thereafter. All taxpayers will benefit.
Principal residences will continue to be fully exempt from tax on capital gains. The $500,000 exemption for small business will not be affected. The federal budget will encourage economic recovery and promote economic growth and job creation. A number of actions will be taken to encourage initiative and productive investment. These measures will promote the healthy growth of the private sector, which is, after all, the only true source of economic growth and job creation.
The manufacturing and processing sector accounts for almost one-fifth of Canada's economy and its jobs. With over 40 per cent of its output exported, this sector has been particularly hard hit by the restructuring of the global economy.
To help the manufacturing and processing sector meet the challenges of globalization, the manufacturing and processing tax rate will be reduced from 23 per cent to 22 per cent, effective January 1, 1993, with a further reduction to 21 per cent on January 1, 1994. The capital cost allowance rate will be increased for manufacturing and processing machinery from 25 to 30 per cent,
February 26, 1992

effective for acquisitions made after today. Hence, the Canadian rate will match the rate in the U.S.
Thanks to these two measures, revenues in this sector will reach $40 million in 1991-1992 and as much as $750 million in 1996-1997.
New activity in all sectors will be encouraged by reducing the withholding tax rate on direct dividends to 5 per cent. This will help Canada compete for international direct investment.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a short observation and a question for my hon. friend from the province of Quebec.
I do not know whether my good friend from Quebec has a co-op housing development in his riding, but I do. I naturally have visited that housing project in my riding. I have talked to the residents there and they are mighty proud of their facility. In this particular development there are elderly people, pensioners, and they are veiy, very happy with the facility. I have not talked to them today, but I am sure that they are very distressed over the announcement coming from the budget that the co-operative housing program has been eliminated by the government.
I should point out that the housing program was certainly a cost-efficient program. It delivered affordable housing to seniors, single parents, disabled and low income earners. Despite the fact that the government sees a saving of something like $25 million over the elimination of the program, I would like to ask my friend from Quebec how he feels about the abolition of the program, whether he thinks it makes sense.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, being an expert in housing in Montreal, it will be easy for me to explain to my colleague the co-operative housing phenomenon.
When you talk about senior citizens, you talk about people who live mostly in low cost housing units. That will continue to exist.
I have built 741 co-operative housing units, and it caused a problem in the Montreal area. People left their residences to move into co-operative or low cost housing units, leaving a whole lot of apartments vacant. Entire buildings are empty. I met people in my riding. Some
The Budget
apartments stayed vacant for 19 months. I know from experience that these people pay taxes but they do not have enough income. Their income is insufficient but they are taxed just the same.
They have to pay the co-ops, but they did not lease their residence. There are lots of apartments like this in Montreal. The present vacancy rate is 7.2 per cent. There has to be a freeze somewhere because people contributing to co-ops will not be able to go on doing so and a disaster is bound to happen. There should be a freeze so that vacant units will be filled and will stay that way. If subsidies are handed out, they should be given to needy people through their revenue. I think it is the best system. Everybody will have some revenue even if they get subsidies. At least, these units will not be vacant while more units are being built and the vacancy rate is
7.2	per cent. It could even reach 7.5 per cent by next summer.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it was interesting to be in the lockup yesterday and be able to look over the budget and look at the pretty gloss on the budget documents, the budget speech and the budget papers. The initial reading of our finance minister's budget speech was one that left sort of a warm fuzzy feeling. And then, as it started sinking in, you realized that what was inside the shiny cover was in fact not as shiny or as bright as it first appeared. I would suggest that in fact it was a cosmetic approach to soften the image of the harsh realities of the last seven and a half years of Tory rule in Canada.
It was interesting to look at some of the press comments, some of the editorials that have been printed today. Particularly interesting was The Globe and Mail which emphasized to me exactly what I had seen when I started, after reading the speech, going into the papers and finding out the harsh realities of what was behind the cosmetic approach. What I found was the same old wrinkled face with a lot of cosmetics caked on it.
In The Globe and Mail they say: "Budget illusion: Some Smoke, Some Mirrors", and in the first paragraph they state: "The latest federal budget accomplishes a neat trick, it stands still but gives the illusion of movement". That is exactly the way I feel about that particular budget. It does give you that warm fuzzy feeling. It does make you feel that, maybe they are doing something, but

The Budget
under scrutiny and under analysis it is obvious that it has gone nowhere.
I would like to touch on a number of things in this budget that concern me, a number of things that I believe are the harsh realities of where this government has gone instead of where it should have gone.
There are a number of things. Perhaps first of all I should say that all in the budget certainly is not bad. There are some positive things. Being a person who likes to talk about the positive, let me talk about some of the positive things. Unfortunately, some of the positive things are tempered by negatives.
I personally feel, as does my party, that the Registered Retirement Savings Plan situation is a good one. The use of Registered Retirement Savings Plans at a time when an injection needs to be made into the economy, particularly in central Canada, makes sense. It makes sense to be able to use some money that is already saved at a reasonable rate and to be paid back over a period of time, thereby answering the critics who say it is for retirement.
Through the use of this particular instrument, it makes it possible for those who have some Registered Retirement Savings Plans but may have difficulty in purchasing a home. That is a positive, but if you analyse what is in the Registered Retirement Savings Plan program, you see that in fact they have opened it up so it can be stacked between spouses. In other words, a husband and a wife can use $40,000 of the Registered Retirement Savings Plan to make a down payment, but it is not for first home buyers. A recommendation of the subcommittee on finance was made within the last few weeks to the Minister of Finance, that it be for first time home buyers only, not necessarily for a new home but for existing housing, thereby helping those who may have been having problems.
By doing what they have done, in effect they have made a situation possible where a couple could live in a home and decide to upgrade. A couple, for instance, my age, who have had the opportunity of paying into registered retirement savings plans and perhaps have $20,000 each in that plan, can pull out the $40,000, move to a new home. There is nothing stopping them from renting out the existing home they have, using their
$40,000 out of their Registered Retirement Savings Plan, interest free for 15 years, and taking any benefit that they have from that particular situation.
That, it seems to me, is once again assistance to those who are in a position already to purchase a home, but opening up a loophole to take bigger advantage of their taxable income.
The upside of this, of course, particularly in the riding of Okanagan-Similkameen-Merritt where we have a good number of saw mills and lumber mills, is hopefully it will create housing starts so that we can begin to sell more lumber and get our economy in those areas going, increasing employment, increasing all of the things we need in the area to get things under way. On the other hand, a little further along we see that the government has cut out over a five-year period $622 million from social housing and terminated co-op housing immediately, costing $25 million.
Those who use the social housing provisions, those who use the co-op housing are normally those in the lower end of the economic scale, those who cannot afford to purchase a house, those who do not have Registered Retirement Savings Plans and certainly do not have $20,000 in Registered Retirement Savings Plans, if they have any in order to put into new housing. They are the ones who usually buy into co-ops so that they have a price they can afford and still say they own their own place. They take pride in that fact that they have been able to bring up their family in housing that they own and that they maintain. They know they can either pass it on or have an investment at some time in their future.
In this budget the government built in something for those who can already afford it while taking away, on the other hand, from those who cannot afford it.
It does not seem to be fair. It seems to be the policies that I have seen over the last seven and a half years, and the policies that I have particularly seen over the last three years while I have been sitting as a member of this House, where we have two classes of people.
We have those who have and those who have not, the rich and the poor. More and more we see the whittling away of the middle class, those in between who can afford a little bit of something. Through taxation, the policies of this government, free trade, increases in
February 26, 1992

unemployment insurance, GST, clawback and you name it, more and more it has hit the middle income earners.
It is interesting to look further and see that in the course of the budget we talk about streamlining. I have no objection to streamlining. I have no objection to making government services more available to the average Canadian. In fact if it were simply that, I would applaud it.
It is interesting to look at the way they talk about it and the type of language they use in the budget papers for this streamlining. They talk about measures to promote improved government service to Canadians.
In the next sub-title, they talk about co-location of services in urban centres and single window services in smaller centres. This does not mean moving all federal public servants in a given city into a single building. That sort of massive relocation would not be cost efficient. Rather, it means co-locating points of service delivery in a rational way and over time to provide better, more convenient service at the lowest possible cost.
If that means giving better service, fine. If it means a continued assault on the rural towns and villages of Canada, then I and my party certainly say: "No. No more. We have had enough". We in the small communities have watched as they have gutted our rural post offices and set up privatized post offices.
We are fighting that right now in Penticton. We are trying to keep the jobs in Penticton, a community of 2,600 where they have closed the main post office. They have privatized and now have threatened 12 more sorting jobs and moving in this type of so-called increase in service to a larger community to the north, Kelowna.
Twelve jobs to a population of 26,000 are a lot of jobs, but I look at this. Does co-location mean taking services and moving them into the larger centres? For instance, in Penticton, we have about 30 people employed by the federal government in veterans' services. They service the whole southeast part of British Columbia, from Merritt in my riding across to the border in Kootenay East.
Does this co-location of service mean that they are going to move this service to Kelowna or Kamloops? It would cost another 30 jobs in the city of Penticton, on top
The Budget
of the potential 12 jobs lost in the post office. If that means also the movement of the Ministry of Health and Welfare, Old Age Security and Canada Pension Branch that employ about three people in that same building with the veterans' services to somewhere else, perhaps to Kelowna, making all of the people in the south end of the Okanagan Valley use a telephone when they are seniors who like to deal face to face, then I say no. My party says no. Enough of this gutting of rural Canada. Let's make services better for people, but let's serve the people. Let's serve the people who we are supposed to be serving. Let's be reasonable about this.
In my critic area of small business, I note in the budget that there are supposed to be some benefits. It seems that they spend a lot of time in the budget papers talking about how good they have been and how well off small business is. Certainly, if we look at the bankruptcy figures over the last two or three years in particular, I think you will agree with me, Mr. Speaker, that they have not been very kind to small business in Canada. In fact the fiscal and monetary policies of this government are driving small business into bankruptcy, into receivership. In some cases those who have not gone broke are moving across the border.
What have they done? They have set up in this budget a small business financing program. Under this program the small business corporation or the unincorporated business will be able to issue small business financing instruments. In talking to the finance department officials, it appears that this is lifted straight out of a bond issue situation act that was prior to 1987 and will probably only apply to banks. Does this mean it is an effort to simply ensure that banks have the opportunity of added insurance against loss? It does not appear to be.
If there was an investor, that investor would be able to come and buy in. In fact, by the next page we see that it is restricted to corporations, individuals who are viewed as being unable to obtain ordinary financing and who are already in financial difficulties. If they have to go out and get the financing because they are in financial difficulty, it is very unlikely that any of the financial institutions are going to take the chance anyway. If they are in financial difficulty, you can be certain that they have already got chattel mortgages and mortgages. They have already got

The Budget
their book accounts tied up. They do not have anything with which to bargain. Who is going to come in after all as a lending institution and take exactly the same amount that they could get by lending somewhere else? It is just not going to happen. It is more window dressing. It is more smoke and mirrors. It is an attempt, it appears to me, to look like they are trying to help the small business community, but it is doubtful that it will work.
The Small Businesses Loans Act increase to $200,000 is applaudable but once again, as has been pointed out in some speeches and questions in the House already, it is apparent that most small businesses are not aware of the Small Businesses Loans Act and, if they were, would not use it at any rate. It is very cosmetic. They have not really looked at the source of what the problem is for the small business community. You do not have to look very far when you look in here and you see that the goods and service tax is bringing in money, and you see what is has cost the small business community over the last year and some months since it was instituted.
Throughout my riding and throughout a number of other ridings across Canada that I have been in since January 1, 1991, it is apparent that not only the small business community has been hurt by the GST. It is apparent that even larger industries, including the forest industry in my area, have all complained about the problems with the GST, the problem with compliance costs. It is interesting to look at the estimates of the Canadian Federation of Independent Business. Their estimate of the cost to business in 1991 is a staggering $6.6 billion to collect the GST for the federal government. They estimate that the cost in 1991 of complying with the collection costs for the GST to small business is $4.5 billion.
This is added on top of the problem they already have in people being so annoyed at the goods and service tax that they are not purchasing any more. They are annoyed that those in the band across lower Canada against the United States border are going across into the United States to buy their goods and in many cases buy their services.
We have to look very carefully at the goods and services tax. There is nothing in this except some wonderful words telling us that the goods and services tax is on target.
It may be on target but it is certainly hurting everyone. If the arrow has hit the target, it is killing small business. I think this government has to face up to that fact and has to do something about it.
Even the Canadian Federation of Independent Business and other businesses have suggested to the government that if it cannot harmonize, cannot knock off the tax on certain things that people normally use or need, such as fuel services and whatnot that are so expensive in Canada, then it should get rid of the goods and services tax. To that I heartily agree.
In order to get this economy going, the government was warned it must drop the goods and services tax.
What hope has this budget given to the average man on the street? Nothing. The government talks about tax breaks, a 1 per cent cutback in the surcharge. That amounts to some $19 in the first year to a person with a $30,000 income. What is that going to do for the economy? That is really something, $19 in the first year. While the government gives $19, it takes back in the other hand.
In this budget the Minister of Finance has admitted to the end of universal family allowance. The first major step was the clawback. The second major step was the admission that universality had ended. Tbday, family allowance; tomorrow, old age pension. Will it be medicare in the future?
I will fight against this. I will fight against cutbacks in the old age security. I will fight against universality attacks by this government in the future on medicare.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think there was a sigh of relief right across the country when it was discovered yesterday that there were no tax increases in the budget.
Most Canadians feel that they are taxed far too heavily. They are fed up with the rate of taxation in the country, so there was that sigh of relief.
However, when we look at the figures, one has to put these tiny decreases in perspective. The previous speaker from British Columbia alluded to this. When it comes to a family earning $40,000, the surtax decrease will be only $27. By the way, that is after raising the taxes $1,000 in recent years. For a one-earner couple with two children, earning $20,000, the finance minister is going to give them a $6 relief. For families earning $15,000, there will be a whopping $2 cut in taxes.
February 26, 1992

It seems to me that we cannot get the cuts much smaller than that. I would like to know what my friend from British Columbia felt about that.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is interesting that the smoke and mirrors continue. This is part of the smoke and mirrors where the government can actually say: "We did give you a tax cut".
It is also interesting to look on the other side of it, when we look at the cost of unemployment insurance over the last little while, where the money is going for unemployment insurance.
The government says that it is supposed to go into training. It does some shifting around and yet it does not do any training. The increase in the unemployment insurance that will kick into effect this year in effect raises the taxes on the average employer and on the average employee. They are all going to have to kick in more for that particular aspect of it.
Let me just say one other thing. One of the other cuts that hits hard at a time of high unemployment-and high unemployment means higher taxes because we all have to kick in or we will have higher deficits-the government has cut $1 million from Canadian Jobs Strategy.
That is an area that has been well used by a number of our ridings, a number of areas within Canada and certainly, within the area of Okanagan-Similkameen- Merritt.
Those types of cuts in my area where the unemployment rate is over 4 per cent higher than the national average cuts hard. The cost of that is incalculable.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am glad the member mentioned unemployment insurance and the cutbacks in retraining funds, despite the fact that there was supposed to be $1.8 billion in the charge-back fund.
Most everybody will understand and recognize the fact that the Department of Employment and Immigration will allow an individual to take a 12, 16 or 20-week course, then go back to the department and may get approved for a separate and isolated program from the
The Budget
first program and if successful, may go for a third separate program.
He or she may get approved for three separate years of training on three different programs, but have refused to approve training for two or three consecutive years which makes eminent sense so that at the end of a retraining program you come out with a certificate.
I have been told by the people in Ottawa that the program is inconsistent across the country. Some employment offices are proceeding with approvals for two and three-year training programs and others have not. It is just a mess.
The people who work in the employment centres have no idea where to go with this. They are saying: "They are grey areas. We are not getting any instruction". They are working on it, but one has to wonder about the sensibility of such an action.
If we want to retrain people, let us do it properly. Let us retrain them so that at the end of their program they have something to show for it, that they really are retrained. I suspect it is somewhat rhetorical, but I would like the member to comment on that.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what I have seen in my area is a similar problem, where there is a lack of consistency between one area and the other.
One of the problems we are running into in those areas through all unemployment retraining programs and for most unemployment insurance programs, is that because of cutbacks people are not getting proper instruction.
People are overburdened with work and cannot keep up with the massive number of applications for either retraining or unemployment insurance. It is a problem.
When they talk about streamlining service I really question that. In my area I have seen that dismantling of the service is closer to the truth of what is happening and that people have to wait and go on welfare.
Over the last few weeks I have had people come to my office from the social services areas around my riding telling me that they cannot get UI and they have had to apply for social assistance. They cannot get job retraining, they have to wait. Some of them have missed the deadline because of the long delays.

The Budget
It is a never-ending problem with these people and this government simply turns its back and says: "We are going to streamline the service".
I agree with the member for Broadview-Greenwood. In fact, they are dismantling all of the systems. The service is going straight downhill. People are not getting what they pay for. They are not getting what they expect and they certainly are not getting what they need.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, thank you for allowing me to take part in this debate. As I begin tonight, I want to quote from the speech of the Minister of Finance yesterday:
I wanted a budget that would deliver a strong bottom line: one that supports the well-being of Canadians and their families; one that promotes the success of our business people in expanding and creating jobs; one that contributes to a strong and more united Canada. And that's the bottom line of the budget I am delivering today.
I think most of us in this House who have analysed that budget would concur with the minister. He has done that.
I go back to a phrase that the minister often uses. I think it is the theme of his budget: "getting the fundamentals correct" or "strengthening the fundamentals". I think he has done that in this budget. What are those fundamentals? Let us look at some of them and maybe help explain them to Canadian people this evening.
The first thing I want to mention with regard to those fundamentals is inflation. It has just been reported that inflation at this point in time in Canada is the lowest it has been in 20 years. It is coming in now at an annual rate of about 1.6 per cent. That is one of those important fundamentals that has to be there for a number of reasons.
We have had many people in our society who have been hurt by the ravages of inflation, not only businesses but our elderly. If we go back to the old rule of 72, which is what they call it in the investment world, any combination of numbers that would equal 72 would give us how much incomes can be eroded when we are taking a look at inflation. If we are taking a look at inflation at 12 per cent for six years, that amounts to 72 per cent. Imagine what that does compounded on top of other expenses
with regard to the real income of average Canadians. We can also apply that with regard to incomes.
The minister has pointed out quite well in this House in recent days that if we can get down to a 2 per cent or 3 per cent annual rate of inflation, the demands by the work force in Canada with regard to wages will come down as well. They will understand that a 5 per cent or 6 per cent increase in wages in relation to a 2 per cent or 3 per cent inflation rate is much better than a 15 per cent wage increase when they are looking at inflation of 11 per cent or 12 per cent.
That fundamental of getting inflation under control is a very important one. As I say, it not only affects our senior citizens but also the working class. I believe that the minister has done that.
If we take a look at interest rates, we see that right now in Canada they are the lowest they have been in 20 years. That has to be good for investment. It is not only good for investment but it is also good for homeowners, those people who are considering purchasing new homes.
As pointed out earlier, the difference between interest rates today and what they were 10 years ago reduces a mortgage on a $75,000 home by over $300 per month. That is very important to recognize because it is a saving for those individual families.
Going back to my opening remarks with regard to inflation, if we are paying less that means we have to earn less. Our demands on our employer are not as great and we have freed up some money to do other things with. Again, it is a very important concept which I think the Canadian people now understand more than they did last year because they can see clear evidence in their daily lives that it is working.
Again I go back to interest rates today versus where they were last year and certainly where they were two years ago. If I go back 10 years, I know we were in the 22 per cent range with regard to interest rates.
Along with that we have to take a look at the value of the Canadian dollar. In Canada we have not decided yet whether we like a low dollar or a high dollar, but we do want a stable dollar. Those fundamentals have to be there in order to achieve a stable dollar, a stable
February 26, 1992

currency. That means the other part of the equation, the debt burden we carry as Canadians, has to be stabilized as well.
That leads me into some of what the minister pointed out yesterday with regard to our debt situation or our deficit situation on an annual basis. He is going to maintain the deficit at somewhere in the order of $31.4 billion this year. Next year it will tumble to $27 billion and go down by approximately $5 billion the year after that. Our target was to reach a point of zero borrowing, where we were actually bringing in revenue not only to pay down the debt and pay the interest on it but simply pay off the principal amount of the debt. That is the secret to the big equation. That is something we have not been able to do as a government, because for many years leading up to 1984 that debt was allowed to multiply at such a rate that when we assumed office we could not generate the necessary dollars to pay it off.
I think that target of being able to pay off the debt or pay down the principal in the year 1995, 1996 or 1997 is achievable. Last year, despite the downturn in the economy, and it was a very tough year, we did not do all that badly. On the revenue side the minister is pretty well on target. Despite a recessionary year he brought the thing in pretty close to target. This year, with an expected growth of something in the order of 3 per cent, I think the goal the minister has set for himself and the government is very achievable.
We have heard in the last number of days-and we have heard it in the House today as well-about the failure of the government to kick-start the economy or jump-start the economy. That brings me back, when I talk about kick-starting or jump-starting the economy, to an editorial I read the other day in The Globe and Mail. It read: "If I hear that term kick-start or jump-start one more time, I am going to call a taxi. When will these people realize that the economy is not like a car engine? It is not like a generator of money that you simply put a charge into it and off you go". We have proven as a country over the years that that just does not work. I do not think we want to follow that course knowing that at the end of the day someone has to pay the bills. Our inability to pay the bills has put us into the difficulty we are in today.
The Budget
We are not going to follow that course. I am very glad to see that the minister has not taken that course. The only way out of debt is to earn our way out of it, work our way out of it, pay it down and pay it off. We are not going to fall into that trap of kick-starting or attempting to jump-start that money machine. It just does not work.
One interesting statistic that I am very proud of in relation to the government is our percentage of debt in relation to our Gross Domestic Product. If we take a look at our projected deficit and in fact what the deficit is today, we have made remarkable progress. In 1984 the ratio of debt to Gross Domestic Product was in the order of 9 per cent, slightly less than 9 per cent. I think it was 8.7, to be exact. Now we are just a little over 4 per cent. We have cut it in half.
It is very interesting to note that some countries in the western world have gone the other way. As we are going down they are going up. I think we are on the correct course because the Canadian economy, as it grows and as we take the types of measures that we have to take and were taken in the budget yesterday, that number will get even smaller. It is a very encouraging number. It does point to some of the things we have done as a government in relation to the fundamentals. It clearly indicates that we do have them right.
One of the topics the minister mentioned yesterday was in relation to interprovincial trade barriers. It is very important that the minister addressed it. As we know, it is one of the proposals that we are trying to address in our constitutional package. I am pleased to see that the minister did address those yesterday.
There are about 500 interprovincial trade barriers between the 10 provinces in this country. At the end of the day they cost us a lot of money. The economists tell us that it costs the average family of four anywhere from $1,000 to $2,500 a year, depending on whose figure you want to accept. It does cost us something. That cost is felt in communities all across this country.
I believe that it is imperative we address these interprovincial trade barriers, especially when we are negotiating and working through our trade agreements with other countries, whether it is with the United States through the FTA or internationally through the GATT.
As we continue to eliminate some of the trade distorting practices and barriers between countries, we have to take a strong look at what we can do here at home.

The Budget
We have been attacked or broadsided on universality and that is putting it mildly. One of the things the minister said yesterday in relation to incomes for poor families, and especially for children in poor families, is veiy refreshing, and that is the system of payment that will go to families which need it. I quote, as the minister did earlier today in the House, what the premier of New Brunswick said about child allowance. He said that there is something ridiculous about a system that allows someone with $100,000 to get child allowance. There are people in my neighbourhood and your neighbourhood who have trouble feeding their families. We should develop a system that addresses the problem a little more realistically. This is what the minister did yesterday.
It was also refreshing to hear yesterday that RRSPs can be used for a down payment on a new or existing home for one year. For example, a married family with both partners having RRSPs would be able to double the $20,000 to $40,000. This is good news for the housing market. It will only be for one year. We are going to try it and we will see how it works. It should be a big boost for the housing people.
In relation to the family, the minister announced that common law couples will not be taxed less than traditional families. It goes back to one of the policies brought forward by our member from Calgary North in support of the family unit. Part of that is the payment that will go to those families in need but the other part of the equation is a fairer tax system for the traditional family. The minister will make that change as well.
The ceiling for small business financing is being raised. In fact it is being doubled, I believe, from $100,000 to $200,000.
Some government agencies are to be eliminated. I have this one highlighted in the budget speech because it is quite interesting. I will step through this if I have the time.
There are a total of 46 separate government agencies that will be affected by the streamlining measures that were outlined yesterday by the minister. Some of these agencies will be wound up or eliminated completely, some will be deferred, others will merge with other agencies. I want to mention some of these. It is important because it is a saving of about $22 million.
I read through this list today for the first time. There are agencies in it I did not know existed. At the end of the day it costs the Canadian taxpayers $22 million. I will mention some of them: the Law Reform Commission, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Veterans Land Administration, the Petroleum Monitoring Agency, the Agricultural Products Board, the Demographic Review Secretariat, CN (West Indies) Steamships Limited-there is one I did not know about-the Science Council of Canada, the Economic Council of Canada, the Pay Research Branch. That is a new one. The Canadian Environmental Advisory Council, the International Aviation Advisory Thsk Force and Committee, the National Advisory Committee on Development Education, the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council and on and on and on the list goes.
Some agencies will be merged and some corporations will be privatized: for example, the Co-operative Energy Corporation, the Cape Breton Development Corporation, the Royal Canadian Mint and the Blainville Motor Vehicle Test Centre, one which I have never heard of.
I think those are all good moves on the part of the minister. As the minister pointed out yesterday, these were signals or messages that he was getting from all Canadians, not just parliamentarians, not just provincial ministers, but ordinary citizens. I have had some of those letters, as all of us have in this House, on ways that the government could cut costs and at the same time maintain services.
I believe that the minister has struck a good balance in this budget. As the member for Fundy-Royal mentioned yesterday, he has been in this House since 1978 and he says it is the first time that he can recall a budget coming in where there was absolutely no tax increases, not even hidden tax increases. I think that is encouraging. A signal was clearly given by the Canadian people, one that the minister acknowledges, that we are heavily taxed as Canadians and at some point we have to draw the line. I think he has drawn it very clearly.
To conclude, before we go into questions and answers and responses, in 1984 this government promised, through the life of its mandate, one million jobs. At the time the government was criticized by all opposition parties, but the fact is that in the life of that first
February 26, 1992

Conservative government, led by our present Prime Minister, we did not create a million jobs. We created 1.5 million. We overshot our objective. We are going to do it again because in this budget the minister is suggesting and anticipating job creation in the order of 500,000 new jobs by the end of 1993.
Because I believe the fundamentals are correct in this budget and the minister is doing the types of things that we have to do, I believe that 500,000 jobs by the end of 1993 will materialize and we will exceed that figure as well.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the member a question. Is it not true that his government has added 34 new taxes, including the GST, which struck disproportionately at low and middle income Canadians?
Is it not true that the government has more than doubled the national debt since taking office, from about $168 billion to $420 billion? Is it not true that it has wreaked havoc for both our manufacturing and natural resource sectors by maintaining the Canadian dollar and interest rates far too high for far too long?
As I said to a member a while ago, they are selling approximately 300,000 ounces of gold monthly on average at the Bank of Canada in an attempt to reduce the deficit and to keep the dollar at levels which are wreaking havoc among Canadians in terms of unemployment.
Is it not true that virtually no Canadian company except the chartered banks and utilities made any profits last year? I am talking about companies listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange, for example. They have allowed the situation to develop in which foreigners now hold about $330 billion in the debt of our national government, our provincial governments and the private sector.
Is it any wonder that The Economist magazine this week, taking 13 advanced industrialized democracies, put us ahead only of Sweden in terms of our economic prospects for the next year. They talk about investment. Why would any intelligent person invest in an economy which has a government that is so bad? In my view, there is not a worse government anywhere in the democratic
The Budget
world, a government that knows so little about basic economics, about creating jobs and keeping jobs that it has done the kind of things I just mentioned.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, to respond to the member, it is bizarre when you think of it. Here is a guy sitting on the other side of the House now who ran for this government in 1984. He sat on this side of the House for four solid years. He ran for this party in 1988 and deserted us when the going got tough. That is the type of guy he is.
The truth of the matter is simply this. There is only one country in the world that has beaten Canada in terms of economic growth in the last six years, that is Japan, but just barely. In fact this year we are going to lead every single country in the world in terms of economic growth, including Japan.
I just want to point something out. We are always talking. They are always trying to derail the FTA because apparently the Americans are getting the best of it.
The truth is that we are doing a heck of a good job when it comes to competing with those guys south of us. What we tend to do is take a look at things with blinders on. We are having our difficulties here in Canada, and we all acknowledge that. We acknowledge that, but the difficulties south of the border do not even come close to what we are seeing. What we see on television every night is not even close to what is really happening there.
It is interesting to note that yesterday the U.S. Commerce Department released some amazing figures with regard to U.S.-Canada trade. Do you know what they told us? These are U.S. figures. In 1991 Canada's exports to the United States stayed right up there at $91.1 billion traded between the two countries.
After everything is said and done, we came out with a $6 billion trade surplus. That means, for the hon. gentleman who just asked the question, it is in our favour. We did better than they did.
We are competing on a daily basis. There are a lot of jobs in this country that depend on trade with other nations. In fact, 40 per cent of our individual wealth as Canadians depends on trade. We are doing a heck of a job.

February 26, 1992
The Budget
I want to give a clarification of those figures. That figure of $91.1 billion is what we shipped to the United States.
After the interchange of goods back and forth, we came out $6 billion better. That tells me we are doing a good job and it tells me that if this member had known what he was doing in 1988 he would have stayed right over here on this side of the House.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have some short comments. First of all, I would like to remind the member for Carleton-Charlotte that my colleague did not desert the government side of the House. He just said to me that he was expelled. We should not leave that misunderstanding in the eyes of the constituents of this country.
When I was listening to the member talk about the inflation rate being 1.6, and it is the lowest inflation rate that we have had in over 20 years, we recognize that. We see that has had some positive effect on the economy.
But one of the negative effects that it has had on this economy is that it has produced this tremendous number of unemployed Canadians, a tremendous number of people who are on welfare.
In this Chamber, this House of Commons, this nation's boardroom, we are not here just to speak for the advantaged and to talk about all the good things that are happening in terms of targets and objectives that we are out to meet. We are here to speak for those in our society who are disadvantaged.
As you are talking about this heavy ratchet you have put on inflation-and I recognize that-you must also recognize the other side of the coin and that is the 3 million people who are out there in deep pain.
We sometimes think that there is a tendency to forget that, you are so excited about the inflation numbers maybe being a year ahead of schedule that you forget about the 3 million people who have been left behind.
I am sure the member for Carleton-Charlotte would agree that it is our responsibility on this side of the House to prick your conscience and remind you about those 3 million people because certainly the Governor of the Bank of Canada is not going to remind you.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the number that the
member uses is 3 million. I want to remind Canadians there are 1.5 million Canadians unemployed, not 3 million. I do not care whether he inflates the number at all. That is his business. Whether it is 1 million, 1.5 million, or 800,000, it is too many Canadians unemployed. We do not argue that point.
As I go back in my remarks earlier, we have to get the fundamentals right in order to get the economy moving. He understands that because he understands the Canadian economy probably more so than anyone else on that side of the House. He does. I have heard some of his speeches.
I do disagree with the number that he uses. The fundamentals have to be there in order to get the economy moving. That is what we are doing because we have to have an inflation rate that businesses can live with, where there is stability in the marketplace and interest rates are down.
I just want to remind the member of his leader. When his leader was part of the government in 1981-82 and the Liberal Party had the government in this country, his leader sat over there.
The unemployment rate at that time was 12.8 per cent and rising. Inflation was 12.9 per cent under the government of which the Leader of the Opposition was a member.
Interest rates at the time were 22 per cent. He corrects me. The Prime Minister of the day was Mr. Trudeau, but the finance minister at the time was the present hon. Leader of the Opposition.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: I rise on a point of order to correct the record, Mr. Speaker. The Minister of Finance at that time was the hon. Allan J. MacEachen.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I only have seven minutes before the day is adjourned. I am going to save the body of my speech for tomorrow morning. I want to finish off responding to my friend from Carleton-Charlotte.
February 26, 1992

One of the reasons we on this side of the House are so concerned about the direction this government is taking us is the massive dismantling job this government has done in the last eight years, from VIA Rail cuts to the cutbacks in the CBC. There is not a thing in this country that has not been touched by this government. It has been one of the biggest dismantling jobs that we have ever seen anywhere in the world.
While the members on the other side tend to gloat on what they call the streamlining of government, they do not seem to realize that a lot of government institutions like the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada are think-tanks that do not always agree with the government. They did not always agree with us when we were in government. They are instruments of provoking and advancing debate.
It is this dismantling that tends to make us very disturbed on this side of the House. Right now we are in the midst of a very serious constitutional debate. Quite frankly I am nervous that this government is in the process of giving away so many powers to the provinces that this place will become redundant; there will be nothing left to do here but send cheques to the provinces.
This country needs a strong national government. This country was built on national programs from coast to coast. That is where we get our national will. That is where we get the thread that binds us as a nation. When times are tough, like the times we have right now, it is this strong national government that pulls us together.
The Budget
Let us take a look at this budget. This budget barely touches retraining. I dare say one of the reasons we do not have a lot of retraining in this budget is that we are in the process of giving it away to the provinces. We are going to constitutionalize training and give it away to the provinces.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I wonder if my friend opposite would advise the House as to why his party opposed the $1.8 billion of UI funds going for retraining.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I am not opposed to the $1.8 billion that we currently use in terms of retraining. When we have 1.5 million people unemployed and another 2.5 million on welfare, that is not enough. When we talk about training and retraining, in the city of Toronto we cannot find spots. We talk in this House about training and retraining, yet when people go to get it, it does not exist. That is the whole problem with this government. This government is one of the most dangerous governments we have ever had in our country's history because it is an expert at communications. It is all tactics and no substance. We are right in the middle of a very serious constitutional debate and I am deathly afraid that this constitutional arrangement that we are playing around with is going to be no different than this budget, just a total sham.
